description: A rich, deeply flavorful traditional dish that combines fresh animal blood with a variety of organ meats (offals) including liver, heart, kidneys, and tripe. This nutrient-dense preparation creates a complex texture and intense savory flavor that is highly valued in traditional cuisine. The blood forms a dark, thick sauce that coats the tender organ meats, resulting in a dish that is both hearty and packed with essential nutrients.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This dish represents the ultimate expression of 'nose-to-tail' eating in Ugandan culture. It is typically prepared immediately after animal slaughter when all the fresh ingredients are available. Different offals may be assigned to specific family members or guests as a sign of respect - for example, the liver might be reserved for elders. The dish is believed to provide strength and vitality, and is often given to new mothers, growing children, or those recovering from illness. Preparing and sharing this meal reinforces community bonds and traditional knowledge about using every part of the animal.

ingredients.name: Fresh Animal Blood
ingredients.notes: Typically goat or cow blood, collected with a pinch of salt

ingredients.name: Liver
ingredients.notes: Cleaned and cut into bite-sized pieces

steps.instruction: Thoroughly clean all offals. Remove any membranes, fat, or blood vessels from the liver, heart, and kidneys. If using tripe, ensure it is well-scraped and cleaned.
Cut the heart into cubes, slice the kidneys, and cut the liver into bite-sized pieces. If using tripe, cut into strips.
Strain the fresh blood through a fine strainer to remove any clots. Add vinegar or lemon juice and mix gently to stabilize.
In a large pot, combine the heart, kidneys, and tripe (if using) with chopped onion, garlic, ginger, and salt. Add 4 cups of water.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 30-40 minutes until the tougher offals are partially tender.
Add the liver and chopped chili peppers. Continue cooking for another 15-20 minutes until all offals are tender but not overcooked.
Reduce heat to very low. Slowly pour the prepared blood into the pot in a thin stream, stirring constantly with a wooden spoon.
Stir gently as the blood begins to coagulate and cook. It will gradually thicken and turn dark brown, coating the offals.

cooking_indicators.visual: The mixture will darken and thicken to a rich, dark sauce consistency

steps.instruction: Add the remaining 2 cups of water and continue to cook on low heat for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally.
The dish is ready when the blood is fully cooked and has a firm but moist texture, and all offals are tender. Adjust seasoning if needed.
Serve hot with your preferred staple food.

serving_suggestions: Serve this rich, nutrient-dense dish with staple carbohydrates like Posho (Ugali), Cassava, or Matoke to balance its intense flavors. The starchy sides help complement the strong taste of the blood and offals. A side of steamed bitter greens like Nakati or Dodo provides a refreshing contrast. Often accompanied by a cold traditional beverage.
